lens.book_chapters: All chapters: Usability Laws and Design Principles

elements.name: People-First Listing Hero
elements.problem_it_solves: Listing pages in the entire room-sharing category organize around property data, burying the human compatibility signals that actually drive the decision to live somewhere.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Every competitor leads with photos, price, and square footage. Split Lease leads with who shares the space, what their schedule is, and what previous guests said about daily life -- answering 'Will I be comfortable here?' in 5 seconds.
elements.description: A listing hero section that inverts the traditional property-first hierarchy. Instead of photos and price dominating the viewport, the hero presents a structured compatibility snapshot: host profile with schedule pattern, stay purpose match indicator, cleanliness protocol summary, and a one-line guest testimonial. Property photos and price are present but visually subordinate. The layout uses a two-column design: left column shows the human reality (host, schedule, lifestyle), right column shows property essentials (photo, price, location).

visual_spec.layout: CSS Grid, 2 columns (60/40 split), stacks to single column on mobile
visual_spec.border: 1px solid #e5e7eb with 2px left accent border in rgb(109, 49, 194)
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple (#31135D) for host name and schedule heading. Secondary purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for the left accent stripe and interactive elements. Accent purple (rgb(140, 104, 238)) for the compatibility match tag. Off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) for the testimonial quote background.

interaction_spec.default_state: Full hero visible above the fold. Schedule badges show host's day pattern. Compatibility tag pulses once on load.
interaction_spec.hover: Host avatar gains purple ring glow (box-shadow: 0 0 0 3px rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.3)). Testimonial section reveals 'Read all reviews' link.
interaction_spec.click: Host avatar opens host profile modal. Schedule badges open detailed weekly schedule view. Testimonial opens full review timeline.
interaction_spec.animation: Compatibility tag fades in with 0.3s ease-out on page load. Schedule badges stagger-animate in (50ms delay each).
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile (<600px), stacks to single column with human section on top, property section below. Photo becomes a compact strip, not a hero image.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Sarah shares this space on weekdays. She works in finance and keeps a quiet, clean apartment.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Schedule match: Your weekday stays align with Sarah's availability
do: Lead with the host's name and one-line lifestyle summary
Show schedule compatibility as a visual pattern, not a percentage
Include a real guest quote about daily life, not a star rating
dont: Do not show a match percentage or algorithm score
Do not hide host information below the fold
Do not use generic placeholder text like 'Great host!'

before_after.before: SpareRoom listing pages lead with a photo gallery, free-text description, and price -- burying housemate profiles in a tiny box below the fold. Users must scroll and read an essay to discover who they would actually live with.
before_after.after: Split Lease leads with the host: name, schedule pattern, lifestyle summary, cleanliness protocol, and a real guest testimonial. The question 'Will I be comfortable here?' is answered in 5 seconds before scrolling.

elements.name: Scaffolded First Contact Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Every room-sharing platform presents a blank message box at the moment of maximum social anxiety -- asking a stranger if you can live with them -- forcing users to compose from scratch with zero guidance.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: SpareRoom and every competitor provide a blank text field. Split Lease transforms the terrifying blank-page moment into a structured, fill-in-the-blanks exercise that reduces cognitive load while acknowledging the emotional weight of the situation.
elements.description: A guided first-contact card that replaces the blank message box with a structured template. It opens with an empathetic micro-copy line ('We know reaching out to someone new takes courage'), then presents three scannable sections the guest fills in: About You (pre-filled from profile), Why This Listing (structured chips for purpose-of-stay), and Your Ideal Dates (calendar picker). A free-text field exists at the bottom for anything else, but the structured sections ensure the host gets the information they actually care about. The card sends a formatted message, not a raw text block.

visual_spec.layout: Flexbox column, max-width 480px, centered within the listing page
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple (#31135D) for section headings. Secondary purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for the send button and selected chips. Accent purple (rgb(140, 104, 238)) for the empathetic header line. Off-white for the header stripe and chip hover states.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card visible with empathetic header, three sections, and a disabled send button. About You section pre-filled from guest profile.
interaction_spec.hover: Purpose chips scale up slightly (transform: scale(1.03)) with purple border. Send button lightens to accent-purple.
interaction_spec.click: Chips toggle on/off with purple fill animation. Calendar picker opens inline. Send button activates when at least one purpose chip and dates are selected.
interaction_spec.animation: Card slides in from bottom with 0.3s ease-out when user clicks 'Contact Host'. Sections stagger-reveal (100ms each). Send confirmation shows a checkmark with a gentle bounce.
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile with increased touch targets (48px min). Calendar becomes a bottom sheet on mobile.

copy_spec.secondary_text: We know reaching out to someone new takes courage. This helps Sarah understand if you're a good match.
do: Acknowledge the emotional weight of first contact explicitly
Pre-fill everything possible from the guest's profile
Show the host's typical response time to reduce void anxiety
dont: Do not say 'Don't worry, it's easy!' -- be empathetic, not dismissive
Do not require free-text composition as the primary input
Do not hide the option to write a custom message for experienced users

before_after.before: SpareRoom shows a blank text field with no guidance. The user must compose from scratch at a moment of peak social anxiety, sending their message into a void with no read receipt or response time expectation.
before_after.after: Split Lease presents a structured card that pre-fills the guest's profile, offers purpose chips, includes a date picker, and shows the host's typical response time -- transforming a thinking-heavy moment into a fill-in-the-blanks exercise.

elements.name: Commitment Journey Breadcrumb
elements.problem_it_solves: After initial contact, every room-sharing platform abandons the user at a cliff edge with zero navigation for the highest-stakes phase -- the path from 'I'm interested' to 'I'm moving in on Tuesday'.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No flatshare platform provides any street signs for the post-contact journey. Split Lease makes every step between interest and move-in visible, navigable, and mindless -- the platform equivalent of Krug's Chapter 6 mall signage applied to the most consequential phase.
elements.description: A persistent horizontal breadcrumb bar that appears once a guest initiates contact on a listing. It shows the complete path from interest to move-in as a series of clear, labeled steps: Introduction Sent, Host Review, Proposal Details, Agreement, Move-In Prep. Each step shows its current status (completed, in progress, upcoming) with a clear indicator of who acts next (you or the host). The breadcrumb is always visible at the top of the proposal flow, providing constant orientation.

visual_spec.layout: Flexbox row, horizontally scrollable on mobile, sticky top position
visual_spec.color_usage: Completed steps use primary purple (#31135D) with white checkmarks. Active step uses secondary purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) with a pulsing ring. Upcoming steps use #e5e7eb gray. 'Your turn' badge uses secondary purple background. 'Host's turn' badge uses light purple outline.

interaction_spec.default_state: All completed steps show purple checkmarks. Active step pulses gently. Upcoming steps are grayed out with labels visible. A 'who acts next' badge sits below the active step.
interaction_spec.hover: Completed steps reveal a tooltip summarizing what happened at that step. Active step shows time elapsed.
interaction_spec.click: Completed steps navigate back to view the details of that step (read-only). Active step scrolls to the current action area.
interaction_spec.animation: When a step completes, the checkmark bounces in (0.3s spring easing) and the connector line fills toward the next step. The 'Your turn' badge slides in from left.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, the breadcrumb becomes horizontally scrollable with the active step centered. Step labels truncate to icons with a tooltip on tap.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Introduction Sent > Host Review > Proposal Details > Agreement > Move-In Prep
copy_spec.micro_copy: Sarah's turn -- she typically reviews within 4 hours
do: Always show who acts next: the guest or the host
Provide time expectations for each waiting step
Allow backward navigation to review completed steps
dont: Do not show so many steps that the path feels bureaucratic
Do not hide the breadcrumb once a step is completed
Do not use vague labels like 'Step 3' -- each step needs a clear description

before_after.before: SpareRoom has zero booking, proposal, or agreement mechanism. After sending a message, users fall off a cliff edge into an entirely unstructured process with no navigation, no breadcrumbs, and no indication of what comes next.
before_after.after: Split Lease shows a persistent breadcrumb bar with 5 clear steps from Introduction to Move-In, always visible, showing who acts next and how long each step typically takes.

elements.name: Host Turnover Checklist
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts like Chantel build elaborate manual systems -- physical books with inventory checklists, cleaning protocols, and turnover procedures -- because no platform supports the active-stay management phase.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: The entire room-sharing category exits the relationship at move-in. Split Lease digitizes the host's manual turnover book into a smart, reusable checklist within the Stays Manager that remembers what was done last time and what needs attention now.
elements.description: A digital turnover checklist card that lives inside the Stays Manager. When a stay cycle ends, the host sees a pre-populated checklist based on their custom protocol: linens changed, inventory verified, cleaning completed, supplies restocked, access codes updated. Items carry over from the host's previous turnover with smart defaults. The card shows a completion percentage and surfaces any items that were flagged in the previous guest's micro-review. It takes the physical checklist book Chantel described and makes it a platform feature.

visual_spec.layout: Flexbox column, compact card within the Stays Manager dashboard
visual_spec.border: 1px solid #e5e7eb, top accent of 3px in rgb(109, 49, 194)
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple (#31135D) for the card heading. Chat purple (rgb(75, 71, 206)) for progress percentage and completed checkmarks. Light gray (#f3f4f6) for unchecked items. Accent purple for flagged items from guest reviews.

interaction_spec.default_state: Checklist visible with items from host's saved protocol. Progress bar shows completion percentage. Flagged items from last guest's review appear highlighted at top.
interaction_spec.hover: Checklist items show a subtle purple left border on hover.
interaction_spec.click: Tapping a checkbox completes the item with a satisfying checkmark animation. Long-press allows editing the item text. 'Add item' button at the bottom.
interaction_spec.animation: Checkmark draws in with a 0.2s stroke animation. Progress bar fills smoothly. Completed items fade slightly (opacity: 0.7) and move to bottom of list.
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile. Checkboxes have 48px touch targets. Swipe-right to complete an item on mobile.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Marcus checks out Mar 25. Next guest Priya arrives Mar 26.
copy_spec.micro_copy: 3 of 8 items complete. Marcus mentioned the bathroom towels were thin.
do: Pre-populate from the host's saved protocol, not a generic template
Surface any flags from the departing guest's micro-review
Show the next guest's name and arrival date for context
dont: Do not create a generic one-size-fits-all checklist
Do not make the host rebuild the checklist from scratch each turnover
Do not feel like surveillance -- this is the host's tool, not the platform's audit

elements.name: Portable Reputation Timeline
elements.problem_it_solves: No platform in the room-sharing category builds portable reputation. Hosts like Cristina cannot remember past guests, and guests must prove themselves from scratch every time because reviews are either unprompted, hidden, or do not exist.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: SpareRoom's references feature is functionally invisible and never prompted. Split Lease accumulates micro-reviews from every stay cycle into a temporal narrative that both hosts and guests carry forward across leases -- creating the first portable flatmate reputation in the category.
elements.description: A visual timeline section that displays a guest's (or host's) accumulated reputation across leases. Instead of a single star rating, it shows a chronological series of micro-review snippets from each stay cycle: Week 1 check-in, Week 4 reflection, midpoint review, and final review. Each entry is a one-line excerpt with the reviewer's context (host name, listing, dates). The timeline grows with each lease, creating a narrative arc that makes returning users recognizable and trustworthy. It appears on both guest profiles (visible to hosts evaluating proposals) and host listings (visible to guests evaluating where to stay).

visual_spec.layout: Flexbox column with a left-side vertical timeline line
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple (#31135D) for section heading and timeline dots. Secondary purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for the timeline line connecting entries. Chat purple (rgb(75, 71, 206)) for lease grouping headers. Gray (#f3f4f6) for individual entry backgrounds.

interaction_spec.default_state: Timeline visible with the most recent lease expanded and older leases collapsed to a summary line. Each entry shows a one-line excerpt.
interaction_spec.hover: Entry cards elevate slightly with purple shadow. Excerpt reveals full review text in a tooltip.
interaction_spec.click: Collapsed leases expand to show all entries. Full review text opens in a slide-over panel. Host/guest name links to their profile.
interaction_spec.animation: Timeline entries stagger-animate in from top (50ms delay each) on first load. New entries slide in from right when added.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, timeline becomes full-width with entries stacking vertically. Collapsed leases show as expandable accordions.

copy_spec.micro_copy: Verified stays only -- each review comes from a confirmed lease
do: Show the chronological narrative, not just an aggregate score
Include context for each review (host name, dates, listing)
Make the timeline grow visibly with each stay, rewarding reputation building
dont: Do not reduce reputation to a single number or star rating
Do not show reviews without the lease context that produced them
Do not allow unverified reviews -- every entry must come from a confirmed stay

elements.name: How Split Lease Works: Self-Evident Explainer
elements.problem_it_solves: Every guest transcript begins with 'how does this work?' because the platform cannot answer its own most basic question. Users call a phone number because the website fails to make the Split Lease concept self-evident.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: SpareRoom and traditional classifieds assume users understand the concept. Split Lease's genuinely novel model (weekly shared living) requires explanation, but this necessity becomes a competitive advantage: the explainer builds understanding AND trust in a single scannable section.
elements.description: A visual explainer section positioned prominently on the homepage and repeated in context on listing pages. It uses a three-step horizontal layout (on desktop) or vertical accordion (on mobile) to answer 'How does this work?' without requiring reading: Step 1 shows a split-week calendar visual (your days vs host's days), Step 2 shows the proposal flow as a simple 3-icon sequence, Step 3 shows the Stays Manager weekly return. Each step has a one-line headline, a two-line description, and an illustrative icon. No walls of text. Krug's rule: if the user cannot get it in 5 seconds by scanning, it is not self-evident.

visual_spec.layout: CSS Grid, 3 equal columns on desktop, stacks to vertical on mobile

typography.heading: Inter 24px/700 #31135D for section title, 16px/700 for step titles

spacing.padding: 48px 32px for section, 24px for each step card

visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple (#31135D) for section heading and step titles. Secondary purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for step number badges and icon accents. Gradient background (off-white to white) to separate from adjacent sections.

interaction_spec.default_state: All three steps visible simultaneously on desktop. Step number badges are prominent circles. Icons animate subtly on load.
interaction_spec.hover: Step cards elevate slightly with purple shadow. Icon within the hovered card animates (calendar flips, arrow slides, checkmark bounces).
interaction_spec.click: Each step card expands to show a 2-3 sentence elaboration below the description. On listing pages, Step 1 is pre-filled with the specific listing's schedule data.
interaction_spec.animation: Steps stagger-animate in from left to right (150ms delay each). Step number badges count up with a number flip animation.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile (<600px), steps stack vertically as collapsible accordions. Step 1 defaults open, Steps 2-3 collapsed with visible headers.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Three steps from browsing to living. No mystery, no guesswork.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Step 1: Share a space, share a schedule | Step 2: Propose your dates | Step 3: Manage your stays
do: Answer 'how does this work?' in under 5 seconds of scanning
Use visual representations (calendar split, arrow flow) not paragraphs
Contextualize on listing pages with the specific listing's schedule data
dont: Do not write a tutorial or an onboarding walkthrough
Do not add 'happy talk' explainer paragraphs -- structure communicates, not more words
Do not assume that once explained, the concept stays understood -- reinforce at each touchpoint

before_after.before: SpareRoom assumes users understand what a flatshare is. Split Lease's genuinely novel weekly-sharing model is never explained on the platform, forcing every guest to call a phone number and ask 'how does this work?'

elements.name: Emotional Milestone Toast
elements.problem_it_solves: The entire room-sharing category treats finding and living with a stranger as a purely transactional process with zero emotional acknowledgment, despite every user transcript overflowing with anxiety, vulnerability, and stress.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor acknowledges the emotional weight of sharing a home with a stranger. Split Lease celebrates real milestones (proposal accepted, first stay completed, positive review received) and provides reassurance at anxiety peaks, making users feel seen rather than processed.
elements.description: A toast notification component that appears at emotionally significant moments in the journey. It is not a generic success message -- it is a context-aware acknowledgment of what the user just accomplished and why it matters. When a guest's proposal is accepted, the toast says 'Sarah accepted your proposal. You have a place in the East Village starting March 2.' When a guest completes their first week, it says 'Your first week is in the books. How did it go?' Each toast has a warm, human tone, uses the actual names and details from the user's journey, and includes an optional action (leave a quick review, see your next stay date). The design is subtle enough not to interrupt flow but present enough to register emotionally.

visual_spec.layout: Fixed position, bottom-right on desktop, bottom-center on mobile
visual_spec.color_usage: Left accent stripe color varies by milestone type: secondary purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for achievements, accent purple (rgb(140, 104, 238)) for celebrations, chat purple (rgb(75, 71, 206)) for reflective moments. White background with purple-tinted shadow.

interaction_spec.default_state: Toast slides in from bottom-right, remains for 8 seconds, then slides out. A progress bar at the bottom shows time remaining.
interaction_spec.hover: Toast pauses its auto-dismiss timer. Shadow deepens slightly.
interaction_spec.click: Action button (if present) navigates to the relevant page. Close button (X) dismisses immediately. Clicking the toast body expands for more detail.
interaction_spec.animation: Slides up from bottom with 0.3s ease-out. Confetti-dot particles (3-4 small purple dots) float upward on celebration toasts only. Auto-dismiss slides down with 0.3s ease-in.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, toast appears as a bottom sheet that covers the bottom 80px. Swipe down to dismiss.

copy_spec.primary_text: Varies by milestone -- always uses real names and specific details
copy_spec.secondary_text: Example: 'Sarah accepted your proposal. You have a place in the East Village starting March 2.'
copy_spec.micro_copy: Example action: 'See your move-in checklist' or 'How was your first week?'
do: Use the actual names, dates, and locations from the user's journey
Celebrate real accomplishments, not manufactured engagement metrics
Vary the tone: warm for first-time milestones, familiar for returning users
dont: Do not celebrate non-events ('You viewed 5 listings!' is not a milestone)
Do not use generic copy ('Congratulations!' without context)
Do not add emotional scaffolding that slows down experienced users -- progressive intensity
